Title:
Population structure and distribution of Colletotrichum spp.
associated with anthracnose of strawberry in central China
Abstract:
The etiology of anthracnose of strawberry is complex, and
several Colletotrichum spp. are causal agents. Multi-locus phylogenetic
analysis of ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GPDH, and TUB2 sequences revealed that 105
strains of Colletotrichum spp. associated with anthracnose of strawberry
in central China belong to six species: C. murrayae, C. fructicola, C.
gloeosporioides, C. aenigma, C. nymphaeae and an probable new specie.
The mycelial growth rates of Colletotrichum spp. isolates at different
temperatures revealed that isolates of all six species had an optimum
temperature of 28ÂºC. The six species were divided into three classes
based on their tolerance to temperature highs. Isolates of C. murrayae
and C. gloeosporioides were more highly tolerant (HT) of temperature
highs (>32Â°C) than isolates of other species. Of the 105 isolates
analyzed in this study, 84 isolates clustered within C. murrayae.
Isolates of C. fructicola and C. aenigma were moderately sensitive (MS)
to temperature highs and were distributed in both high- and
low-elevation areas. Isolates of C. nymphaeae and C. kahawae, which are
only distributed in high-elevation areas (1100 m), were highly sensitive
(HS) to temperature highs. These results indicate that tolerance to
temperature highs is an important factor in the distribution of
Colletotrichum species on strawberry plants. This research may increase
our understanding of how Colletotrichum spp. emerge and spread to
geographical regions with different latitudes or elevations.
